awd_titl_txt: Optically-controlled neuromodulation with silicon carbide-based nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Extracellular electrical stimulation of neurons and heart cells, the standard means by which to study excitability, forms the basis for many implantable disease-treating devices including those for Parkinson's disease, depression, epilepsy, and cardiac arrhythmias.  While these neural modulation devices have improved patients' quality of life, they are challenging to deploy in many animal studies due to being bulky, invasive, complex and expensive, thus limiting their use in basic neuroscience studies.  The goal of this project is to demonstrate flexible and cost-effective silicon carbide (SiC)-based nanostructures that, when triggered by light, can modulate the behavior of single neurons. These new SiC-based interfaces will enable wireless, non-genetic, multiscale, precise modulation of neurons, overcoming many of the limitations of current implantable electrodes.  This project will provide learning opportunities for students in a highly interdisciplinary area. The investigator will build on existing model programs at the University of Chicago to increase diversity in science and engineering by offering summer research opportunities to high school and undergraduate students. An international summer exchange program that allows undergraduate and graduate students to visit Israel will be continued and a special training program for outstanding high school students to compete in national competitions (e.g., Regeneron Science Talent) will be expanded. The research and education results will be disseminated broadly through peer-reviewed publications, seminars, conference presentations, and websites.

Optogenetics has emerged as the leading modern approach for neuromodulation, but it is difficult to deploy in many animal model systems. Recently developed semiconductor and metal-based biomaterial interfaces have the potential to provide with relative ease the non-genetic and multiscale neural activities in a very broad range of animal model systems. However, the large-scale fabrication or synthesis methods for these materials and devices are usually very complex and expensive. Additionally, there is a lack of studies of both excitatory and inhibitory neuromodulation from the same class of materials. This project addresses these two limitations through use of silicon carbide (SiC) as a material to construct neural interfaces for optically triggered non-genetic neuromodulation.  The Workflow Plan is presented as three consecutive steps: (1) innovation of synthetic methods for the large-scale silicon carbide synthesis and device fabrication, to (2) study both the excitatory and inhibitory responses using cultured neurons, and finally to (3) deployment and proof-of-concept testing in a mouse model. This project will bring together an efficient, multi-level, cross-disciplinary approach to achieve the large-scale and stable photoelectrochemical devices for random-access neuromodulation in the brain. The proposed study will also offer a unique knowledge and skill set that can open new areas of endeavor in the semiconductor or detector industry. The silicon carbide-based membranes studied in this work can potentially yield highly efficient biomedical devices for translational studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the development and application of silicon-based and carbide-based materials for optically controlled neuromodulation. Neuromodulation, a technique to regulate neural activity, has emerged as a critical tool in neuroscience and bioelectronics. The aim of our work was to create scalable, sustainable, and precise biointerfaces that address limitations in current approaches, including cost, complexity, and environmental impact. Our research explored materials and devices that enable precise neural and cardiac modulation without requiring genetic modifications or invasive techniques. Alongside advancing scientific understanding, we also prioritized education and outreach to build a foundation for the next generation of researchers.

Intellectual Merit

The research focused on silicon-based and carbide-based materials to achieve non-genetic, optically controlled neuromodulation. A primary goal was to create biointerfaces that are both functional and scalable. Through innovative laser-assisted chemical conversion and additive manufacturing techniques, we developed materials with exceptional properties, including high electrical conductivity, mechanical flexibility, and compatibility with biological systems. Notably, porous silicon-carbon hybrid materials demonstrated particular promise for neural and cardiac modulation. These materials were integrated into devices capable of stimulating tissues with precision and minimal invasiveness.

A major advancement was the design of silicon-based photoelectrochemical devices capable of random-access photostimulation. These devices allowed high-resolution, localized stimulation of neural circuits, offering insights into the complexities of neural networks and potential therapeutic applications. Testing in rodent models revealed that these devices could facilitate synchronized limb movements and cardiac pacing at reduced power thresholds, demonstrating their translational potential. Additionally, our team developed a roll-to-roll manufacturing process, enabling the continuous production of these devices on recyclable substrates. This process reduced fabrication costs while maintaining an environmentally conscious approach.

The intellectual merit of this work extends beyond technical development. By addressing both performance and sustainability, our research bridges critical gaps between material science and bioelectronics. Findings from this project have been disseminated through leading journals such as Nature and Nature Sustainability, highlighting the potential impact of silicon-based and carbide-based materials in advancing bioelectronics.

Broader Impacts

The project’s broader impacts include significant contributions to education, diversity, and sustainable practices in STEM fields. Undergraduate and graduate students were actively involved in interdisciplinary research that combined material synthesis, biointerface engineering, and photostimulation technologies. This provided them with a strong foundation in cutting-edge techniques while fostering a collaborative and innovative research environment. Students were encouraged to approach scientific challenges critically and creatively, enhancing their confidence and capacity to contribute meaningfully to the field.

A critical aspect of this initiative was its emphasis on diversity and inclusion. To this end, summer research programs were developed to engage high school and undergraduate students from underrepresented communities in the southern region of Chicago. These programs aimed to expand access to scientific opportunities, inspire interest in STEM fields, and provide early exposure to advanced research methodologies. Participants gained hands-on experience and mentorship, fostering a sense of belonging in scientific and academic communities.

The project also demonstrated a commitment to sustainability. The roll-to-roll manufacturing process for device production reduced the environmental footprint typically associated with advanced material fabrication. By using recyclable substrates and minimizing energy consumption, this approach highlighted the possibility of harmonizing technological innovation with environmental responsibility.

The outcomes of this research have been widely disseminated through publications, conference presentations, and educational initiatives. Graduate student Jiuyun Shi, who was supported by the project, received multiple prestigious honors, including the Forbes 30 Under 30 recognition in the Science category. This accolade celebrates his innovative contributions to materials research and neuromodulation. Other students involved in the project have also achieved notable milestones, including co-authoring papers in high-impact journals such as Nature.

Conclusion

The project has provided valuable contributions to the fields of neuroscience and bioelectronics, particularly in the development of silicon-based and carbide-based materials for neuromodulation. The integration of innovative materials, scalable manufacturing processes, and practical applications has demonstrated the feasibility of creating biointerfaces that are both effective and environmentally responsible. These advancements have implications for therapeutic neural and cardiac modulation, as well as broader applications in bioelectronic medicine and environmental sensing.

While the project’s scientific achievements are noteworthy, its broader impacts in education and diversity are equally significant. By engaging students from diverse backgrounds and emphasizing sustainable practices, this work has helped to build a more inclusive and environmentally conscious scientific community. Looking forward, the results from this research lay a foundation for continued exploration and innovation in bioelectronics, with the potential to address pressing medical and societal challenges.
